columns.text:
In this problem, we need to determine effective annual
interest rate which the buyer is paying if he not taking the discount, and then explain what will happen to this effective interest  rate under the given conditions.

Company offers terms of $1/10$, net $30$. This means if a buyer pay within $30$ days for the invoice date, supplier will grant them $1$ percent discount on the full price, or buyer will pay the full amount within $30$ days of the invoice date. 

The simple interest rate for the term of the discount is $\frac{0.01}{0.99}=0.010101$. This is an interest rate for $20$ days. There are $\frac{365}{20}=18.25$ such periods in a year.

Without using the discount, the buyer pays an effective annual interest rate of 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{EAR}&=\left(1+0.010101\right)^{18.25}-1\\
&=1.010101^{18.25}-1\\
&=1.2013-1\\
&=0.2013\hspace{2mm}\text{or}\hspace{2mm}20.13\%
\end{align*}$$

**a)**  If a discount is changed to $2$ percent, then the simple interest rate  will be $\frac{0.02}{0.98}=0.0204$ which is higher than the previously calculated interest rate. So, by substituting in the formula for the effective interest rate we get EAR which is greater then $20.13\%$. 
Hence, if discount increase, then EAR also increase.

**b)** If a  credit period is increased to $45$ days,then interest rate $0.010101$ is a rate for $35$ days. There are $\frac{365}{35}=10.43$ such periods in a year. So, the number of period in a year is less then $18.25$, Substituting this obtained number of periods in formula for EAR, we get the less result  then $20.13\%$. 
Hence, when a credit period increase, then the effective interest rate decrease.

**c)**  If a  discount period is increased to $14$ days, then intersst rate $0.010101$ is the rate for $16$-day period. Then, here will be $\frac{365}{16}=22.81$ such periods in a year. Substituting this obtained number of periods in formula for EAR, we get the greater result  then $20.13\%$. 
Hence, when a discount period increase, then the effective interest rate also increase.
